description.narrative: To mainstream biodiversity conservation into riverine landscapes through improved river planning and management practices in Malaysia.

activity-description.narrative: Mainstreaming river management into biodiversity conservation

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1: Development of a formalized mechanism for inter-agency collaboration to mainstream biodiversity into river management. 1.2: Best management practices guidelines that systematically address the management of riverine biodiversity conservation in Malaysia context. 1.3: Federal government budget allocated for implementation of riverine biodiversity management strategy and action plan including establishment of a biodiversity/ecosystem unit within DID. 1.4: Improved capacities of national agencies responsible riverine biodiversity conservation as shown by an increase in riverine conservation capacity development scorecard. 1.5: Percentage of key agency staff and other national and state level stakeholders targeted by the campaign whose knowledge, attitudes and practices change in relation to riverine biodiversity and ecosystem services, the approach needed for a holistic and integrated approach for effective river management, and the responsibilities of different stakeholders. 2.1: Pilot demonstration 1- in upper Kinta Basin improves status of riverine biodiversity through strengthen watershed management 2.2: Riverine biodiversity management integrated into planning and implementation of Klang River of Life Programme 2.3 Riparian habitat protected and enhanced in partnership with the private sector and local communities in Segama river basin

comment.narrative: 1.1: No formalised mechanisms exist at national level for the inter-agency collaboration on riverine biodiversity management. 1.2: Best management Practice guidelines available on some relevant topics but not comprehensive or easily accessible. Lack of economic information on riverine ecosystem services including tourism to underpin policy and planning. 1.3: No specific allocation for riverine biodiversity management; no dedicated staff within DID for riverine biodiversity management. 1.4: Baseline score 17% at Nov 2014. 1.5: Baseline to determined at outset of specific awareness activities. 2.1: Eroding slopes to be established using GIS in year 1; low level of forest clearance for orchards in traditional lands (less then 5ha per year); lack of mainstream approach on biodiversity; copper mahseer population impacted by high sediment loading from sloe erosion. 2.2: Limited formal adoption of river stretches; declining population such as Tor tambroides due to habitat loss; very low awareness of the risks of the alien invasion species. 2.3 : 40km riparian zone rehabilitated by sbah Mas by Dec 2014; no local community engagement; no systematic monitoring in place; patchy baseline information on riparian key species distribution. 2.4: No project supported activities underway.

1) Establish technical committee (TWG) to appoint a consultancy company to undertake the implementation of Component 1 2) Appoint responsible parties to implement activities in the three project sites for Component 2 3) As recommended by IRR, the project will request for 18-month project extension by May 2020.

1) A technical committee (TWG) to appoint a consultancy company to undertake the implementation of Component 1 was established. The committee had convened thrice (26 June, 4 November and 2 December 2020) to discuss and finalize the TOR. A closed advertisement was performed (invitation to select companies to participate) on 14 December 2020. 2) Two responsible parties (Global Environment Centre and Forever Sabah) were appointed to undertake implementation of Component 2 at three project sites namely Upper Kinta Basin (Perak), Sg. Klang River Basin (Selangor and Wilayah Persekutuan) and Sg. Segama (Sabah). 3) The project has successfully requested for project extension. The approval by UNDP Nature, Climate and Energy was obtained on 21 August 2020. The project is extended for 18-months with new date of closure on 9 May 2022.

1) Proposed integration of biodiversity in the draft stage of any policy such as National Agrofood Policy etc. 2) Guidelines for management of riverine biodiversity developed, adopted and made widely available for application by KATS and DID. 3) Score on the Capacity Development Scorecard increases by 50% by end of project 4) Agencies/section(s) responsible for riverine ecosystem/biodiversity management are clearly specified at national 5) (i) At least 1 site established and demonstrated using bioengineering techniques (ii) 5 communities actively monitoring on quarterly basis in Upper Kinta Basin 6) (i) Riverine habitats will be enhanced at the following four sites: S1: Kampung Taman Warisan, S2: Bukit Kiara (Sg Penchala), S3: Sg Gombak (KRT Seri Terengganu), S4: Taman Melawati; (ii) At least 50 percent awareness of Aquatic Alien Invasive Species (AIS) risk among targeted registered aquarium shops and angler’s association/groups 7) (i) at least an additional 20km of riparian habitat enhanced/ conserved by end of project period; (ii) At least 20 villagers from targeted village involved in river monitoring 8) (i) Site 1: Orang Asli from at least 20 households trained and receive income from tourism and slope protection and rehabilitation activities; (ii) Site 2: At least 20 households actively participate in community groups promoting river quality improvements; (iii) Site 3: At least 20 households trained and receive income from tourism, handicraft and seafood processing activities; (iv) At least gender equity achieved in all sustainable livelihood activities through engagement of female facilitators for community groups

1) Proposed integration of biodiversity in the draft stage of any policy such as National Agrofood Policy etc. 2) First draft of guidelines for management of riverine biodiversity and action plan developed and will be completed by May 2022. 3) Agencies/section(s) responsible for riverine ecosystem/biodiversity management are specified at draft action plan. 5) (i) Riverine habitats were enhanced at the following three sites: S1: Rumah Pangsa AU2, S2: Sg Gombak (PA Seri Terengganu), S3: Taman) Melawati (ii) Zero percent awareness of Aquatic Alien Invasive Species (AIS) risk among targeted registered aquarium shops and angler’s association/groups 6) (i) 40 km stretch of riparian habitat in Segama River was enhanced. (ii) 104 villagers from 9 villages were involved in Segama river monitoring / conservation.
7) Site 1: 18 Orang Asli were trained and receive income from tourism and slope protection and rehabilitation activities (Ulu Sg. Kinta); Site 2: 25 individuals from 13 community groups actively participated in community groups promoting river quality improvements (Ulu Sg. Klang); Site 3: 104 individuals from 9 villages were trained and received income from tourism, handicraft and seafood processing activities. Gender equity achieved in all sustainable livelihood activities through engagement of 5 female facilitators for community groups.

Due to the lack of implementation progress in the past years, the project needs to undertake an Independent Rapid Review (IRR) to review the project’s strategic results framework (SRF), re-evaluate the current pilot demonstration project sites and provide recommendations to improve the project’s implementation.

An Independent Rapid Review (IRR) was commissioned between August and November 2019 to identify bottlenecks and recommend solutions to put the project back on track. Following the IRR’s recommendations, the project has delivered the six recommendations below by end of 2019:
• National implementation modality strengthened and enhanced with management support within project management unit in Department of Irrigation and Drainage. • Short term adaptive management plan achieved by end of 2019 which includes conducting capacity assessment of responsible party, inception workshop and finalization of SRF. • Ownership, governance, meeting cadence and communication / meeting protocol clarified with Department of Irrigation and Drainage and Ministry of Environment and Water (previously Ministry of Water, Land and Natural Resources) and endorsed by National Steering Committee on 6 February 2020. • A short-term project manager was on-board in December 2019 to implement and fast track activities. • Implementation phase commenced after recommendation 2’s actions were completed. • Delivered early value in the first Quarter of 2020.
The IRR’s recommendation was that the project should apply for extension if early values were delivered in the first quarter of 2020.

1) Complete Terminal Evaluation by February 2022. 2) Conduct Mainstreaming Biodiversity Conservation into River Management in Malaysia by March 2022 3) Completion and printing of Best Management Practices guideline and disseminate to all relevant government agencies and stakeholders 4) Project to operationally close on 9 May 2022 and financially closed by 9 November 2022
